close_symbols: struct MHD_Daemon (definition; at least fields: options, tid, connections_head, connections_tail, urh_head, urh_tail, listen_fd, was_quiesced, connections, connection_limit, at_limit, itc, shutdown, have_new, data_already_pending)
struct MHD_Connection (definition; at least fields: next, prev, socket_fd, event_loop_info)

struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle (definition; fields: next, prev, connection, mhd.socket, in_buffer_size, out_buffer_size, in_buffer_used, out_buffer_used, clean_ready, was_closed) [only if HTTPS_SUPPORT && UPGRADE_SUPPORT enabled]
resume_suspended_connections (function/prototype and side‑effects on daemon state)
call_handlers (function/prototype and side‑effects on connection list)
urh_to_pollfd / urh_from_pollfd / process_urh (prototypes and side‑effects) [if HTTPS/UPGRADE enabled]
struct pollfd (definition; at least fields: fd, events, revents)
MHD_POLL_EVENTS_ERR_DISC and MHD_POLL_REVENTS_ERR_DISC (macros used in poll event masks)
explanation: To decide whether any controlling expression in MHD_poll_all is invariant (MISRA C rule), the analyst must know which operands are compile‑time constants and which can change at run time (including changes by called functions). The struct definitions (MHD_Daemon, MHD_Connection, and, if relevant, MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle) are required because many controlling expressions directly read daemon or connection fields (options, tid, listen_fd, was_quiesced, connections, connection_limit, at_limit, itc, shutdown, have_new, connections_head/tail, connection->next/prev/socket_fd/event_loop_info, etc.). The thread‑ID macros/functions (MHD_USE_SELECT_INTERNALLY, MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_ID_, MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_current_thread_) are used in mhd_assert controlling expressions — their semantics and values determine whether those assertions are invariant. The suspend/resume macros/values (MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME, MHD_NO) and the function resume_suspended_connections are required because they appear in a conditional that can short‑circuit execution and change millisec; resume_suspended_connections may also mutate daemon state. Socket/ITC/poll related macros and functions (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET, MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_, MHD_itc_r_fd_, MHD_itc_clear_, struct pollfd, POLLIN/POLLOUT, MHD_POLL_EVENTS_ERR_DISC, MHD_POLL_REVENTS_ERR_DISC, MHD_sys_poll_, MHD_socket_get_error_, MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_EINTR_) are needed to assess whether the poll-related if/tests and revents checks are invariant or depend on external events. The functions that may mutate the connection lists (new_connections_list_process_, MHD_accept_connection, call_handlers, MHD_connection_finish_forward_, MHD_resume_connection and the urh helpers urh_to_pollfd/urh_from_pollfd/process_urh) must be known because they can change the loop controlling expressions (pos != NULL, indices vs num_connections, fd comparisons) between iterations — i.e., make what might appear invariant actually variant at runtime. Finally the event‑info enumerators (MHD_EVENT_LOOP_INFO_*) are required to interpret the switch controlling expression and determine whether associated actions (and thereby timeout changes) can make related conditions non‑invariant. Together these symbols let an analyst determine which controlling expressions are truly constant at compile/run time and which can vary due to state or side‑effects, which is necessary to judge compliance with the MISRA invariant‑control rule.
